Subject: Illustrations - Switzerland - 1476|~|Nasal Polyps - surgery|~|Surgical Instruments|~|Nose - surgery
Title: One instrument for nasal surgery, in text.
Description.abstract: In middle of r. column, drawn in blue, a right-angled blade with a two-winged handle, used for cutting within the nose. Chapter title preceding image: De polippo et ulceribus que fiunt in naso. Adjacent text: Guy de Chauliac's Chirurgia magna, Book 4, Doctrine 1, Chapter 2.
Description.note: Luterbach, Switzerland(?), 1476(?)|~|Text immediately preceding image: Significantur iste passiones apercendo nares cum instrumento ... speculum cuius forma est ista.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 25 (Guy de Chauliac. Chirurgia). fol. 105
Relation.isPartOf: Guy, de Chauliac, ca. 1300-1368. Chirurgia magna.

Subject: Illustrations - Switzerland - 1476|~|Surgical Instruments|~|Rectal Fistula - surgery
Title: 2 surgical instruments for rectal surgery, in text.
Description.abstract: Two instruments for the removal of anal fistulae. The first, drawn in red in upper r. column of text, is a sickle-shaped scalpel. The second, in blue in lower r. column, is a needle-like probe with an eye in the middle. Chapter title preceding images on fol. 111v: De fistula que in ano est. Dimensions of each image: 10 x 40 mm. Adjacent text: Guy de Chauliac's Chirurgia magna, Book 4, Doctrine 2, Chapter 7.
Description.note: Luterbach, Switzerland(?), 1476(?)|~|Text immediately preceding first image: Modus incisionis cum falce que est secundum albucasis instrumentum tale.|~|Text immediately preceding second image: ... pro foramen cordule instrumentum tale.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 25 (Guy de Chauliac. Chirurgia). fol. 112
Relation.isPartOf: Guy, de Chauliac, ca. 1300-1368. Chirurgia magna.|~|http://ihm.nlm.nih.gov/luna/servlet/view/search?q=A027128

Subject: Illustrations - Switzerland - 1476|~|Mouth - surgery|~|Surgical Instruments
Title: Three surgical instruments for the mouth. Page 1
Description.abstract: Three instruments for surgery on the mouth, simply but recognizably sketched, in text: the first, at center r. of fol. 161, in red ink partly filled in in blue (perhaps to indicate a hollowing) shows a sickle (falx) shape; the second, at bottom l. of fol. 161, also outlined in red ink with blue filling, shows a tube or "canula" with a window or "fenestra" at its upper r. and a handle or ring at its l. end; the third, at center l. of 161v, in red ink, another tube, perhaps combined with spatula for application of corrosives, round handle or ring at l. end, spatula(?) protruding at r. Adjacent text: Guy de Chauliac's Chirurgia magna. Dimensions of image: 60 x 10 mm.
Description.note: Luterbach, Switzerland(?), 1476(?)|~|Chapter title preceding images: De passionibus labilorum erghiginarum et qazqazeorum.|~|Text immediately preceding first image: ... cum spatumine falce facilius incidatur, ut hic:|~|Text immediately preceding second image: Secundo modo cum ferro ... quod habeatur canula in capite cuius in alto et latere sit fenestra in quia includetur uvula, ut hic:|~|Text immediately preceding third image: Caveatur tum ne aliquid medicinarum acutarum descendit inferius neque tanquam at alias partes quare deleret eas. Modus instrumenti tertii est hic:
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 25 (Guy de Chauliac. Chirurgia). fol. 161-161v.
Relation.isPartOf: Guy, de Chauliac, ca. 1300-1368. Chirurgia magna.

Subject: Illustrations - Switzerland - 1476|~|Shoulder Dislocation - surgery|~|Surgical Instruments
Title: Three numbered instruments for treatment of a dislocated shoulder.
Description.abstract: Three instruments for the treatment of a dislocated shoulder, numbered 1-3 and drawn in red and blue in the middle of the l. column. The first is shaped as a shield with a long horizontal on line on top representing a leather strap ("aluta"); the second is a closed u-shape; the third is triangular. Adjacent text: Guy de Chauliac's Chirurgia magna.
Description.note: Luterbach, Switzerland(?), 1476(?)|~|Text immediately preceding images: ... desuper emplastrum in loco in quo apparebit eminentia extensum in alutam forma scuti et remutetur de ... in ... diebus.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 25 (Guy de Chauliac. Chirurgia). fol. 165
Relation.isPartOf: Guy, de Chauliac, ca. 1300-1368. Chirurgia magna.

Subject: Illustrations - Switzerland - 1476|~|Surgical Instruments|~|Cautery - instrumentation
Title: Twelve surgical instruments for cautery, in text.
Description.abstract: Twelve cautery instruments appearing in six groups: at center r., in red ink, a knifelike "cutellarus" appears just above stiletto-like "olivare;" at bottom l., in blue ink, "dactilare" resembles a bar with knobs at each end; at top right, in red ink, "punctale" resembles an awl with knobs just above the handle; at centre r., two plates or "plata, the first in blue ink, the second in black, a probe in black ink, and a "canula" or tube in blue ink; at lower r., in red ink, a lancelike blade and hooklike instrument, both with long handles, are crossed scissorlike, joined by a cuplike object they both pass through, apparently to form the "cauterium subtile;" at lower r., three rounded plates of the type called "circulare" the two smaller, l. one in black and one in red, and the larger, r. in blue ink.  Chapter title on fol. 183v preceding image series: De cauteriis et formis ipsorum. Adjacent text: Guy de Chauliac's Chirurgia magna Book 7, Chapter 3. Dimensions of images: 60 x 30 mm.
Description.note: Luterbach, Switzerland(?), 1476(?)|~|Text preceding first image at center r. of text: Prima forma est cutellari ad formam cutelli facta ... cuius forma est talis:|~|Text following second image at center r. of text:Secundum instrumentum est olivare ...|~|Text following third image at bottom r. of text: Tertium instrumentum est dactilare ...|~|Text following fourth image at top r. of text: Quartum instrumentum est punctale gratilem et rotundum cum quo est cauterizatur sola cutis ...|~|Text preceding a group of four more images at center r.:... ut non offendat latera cum quo cauterizantur in membra profunda ut fistula lacrimalis pollyppus infra nasum et dentes. Cuius forma primi plata est talis.  Forma sed secundae canulae est talis:|~|Text preceding the ninth image (labelled as the fifth) at lower r: Quintum instrumentum est cauterium subtile quo ponuntur tetones ... cuius forma est talis ut hic:|~|Text to the right of ninth image (apparently referring to the last three at bottom): Sextum instrumentum est circulare et quibusque additamentis ad faciendum quaeque.|~|Text preceding three final images, grouped at bottom r.: cauterici ad nodum cum plata quaeque foraminibus perforata ... cuius forma est talis plata:
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 25 (Guy de Chauliac. Chirurgia). fol. 185v
Relation.isPartOf: Guy, de Chauliac, ca. 1300-1368. Chirurgia magna|~|Schullian & Sommer.  Catalogue of incunabula and manuscripts in the Army Medical Library, p. 238.

Subject: Illustrations - Switzerland - 1476|~|Surgical Instruments|~|Head Injuries - surgery|~|Trephining - instrumentation
Title: 9 instruments for head surgery. Page 2
Description.abstract: Nine instruments for the treatment of head wounds. On fol. 86v, towards bottom r., (1) a black sharp-pointed trephin; at bottom r. of that folio, (2) a similar instrument drawn in red, but with cutting edge not colored in. Other instruments are contained within fol. 87, l. column; (3) a lance-like triangular instrument perhaps another trephin,in red; (4) a straight-edged wedge-like elevatory in black with red outline; (5) a red instument, perhaps another elevatory, in the form of a hook-like curved blade; (6) an elevatory in the form of a blue rod with protrusions in opposite directions at each end; (7) rugine in the form of a black, slightly curved, flat-ended blade with blue handle; (8) a blue flat-bladed scalpel-like lenticular; and (9) a red hammer or mallet. Chapter title on fol. 86 preceding image series: De instrumentis cum quibus fit operatio in vulneribus capitis. Adjacent text: Guy de Chauliac's Chirurgia magna, Book 3, Doctrine 2, Chapter 1.
Description.note: Luterbach, Switzerland(?), 1476(?)|~|Rubricated text immediately preceding first image: Trepana.|~|Rubricated text immediately preceding second image: Trepana.|~|Text immediately preceding third image: ad modum lancee ...|~|Rubricated text immediately preceding fourth image: Separatorium.|~|Text immediately preceding fifth image: eam faciunt turnam ...|~|Rubricated text immediately preceding sixth image: Elevatorium.|~|Rubricated text immediately preceding seventh image: Rugina.|~|Rubricated text immediately preceding eighth image: Lenticularia.|~|Rubricated text immediately preceding ninth image: Malleus.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 25 (Guy de Chauliac. Chirurgia). fol. 86v-87
Relation.isPartOf: Guy, de Chauliac, ca. 1300-1368. Chirurgia magna

Subject: Trachea - surgery|~|Neck - surgery|~|Illustrations - Switzerland - 1476|~|Surgical Instruments
Title: One instrument for neck wound surgery.
Description.abstract: Instrument for cutting in the neck area, drawn in red at bottom of r. column. Rubricated text preceding image, on fol. 91v: de vulneribus ventus et partium eius; on fol. 93 de sutura ventus. The instrument is a sharp-pointed scalpel. Adjacent text: Guy de Chauliac's Chirurgia magna.
Description.note: Luterbach, Switzerland(?), 1476(?)|~|Rubricated text immediately to left of image: Bitofos toma siringa.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 25 (Guy de Chauliac. Chirurgia). fol. 93
Relation.isPartOf: Guy, de Chauliac, ca. 1300-1368. Chirurgia magna.

Subject: Books|~|Authorial portraits - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Students|~|Historiated initials - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Teaching|~|Teachers
Title: Teacher, perhaps Johannitius, and student.
Description.abstract: The image is found within a historiated initial "M" of "Medicina" at top r. of leaf.  Within the left-hand curve of the blue letter, a professor (Johannitius, more properly Hunain Ibn Ishaq?) sits lecturing a student in the right-hand curve.  The professor holds a book in his l. hand (the Tegni of Galen?) and points to it with his r.  He wears a green gown with a red robe.  The student wears a blue gown with a red robe, and holds a notebook.  Adjacent text:  Johannitius's Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni.
Description.note: Oxford, England, ca. 1250.|~|Attributed to the artist associated with William de Brailes in the Cockerell psalter.|~|Rubricated text immediately preceding image: Incipiunt ysagoge iohannicii ...|~|Text immediately to the right of image: Medicina in duas partes dividitur ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts]. [ca. 1250] DeRicci/Bond & Faye [78] fol. 1
Relation.isPartOf: Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq al-Ibādī, 809?-873. Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni.|~|Kraus.  Catalogue 126, p. 19.

Subject: Books|~|Authorial portraits - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Hippocrates|~|Historiated initials - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Teaching|~|Teachers
Title: Physician, perhaps Hippocrates, holds book.
Description.abstract: In initial "V" of "Vita," a Teacher (Hippocrates?) sits on a white chair holding a book ( the Aphorisms?).  He wears a blue gown under a red robe.  Adjacent text:  Hippocrates' Aphorismi.
Description.note: Oxford, England, ca. 1250.|~|Attributed to the artist associated with William de Brailes in the Cockerell psalter.|~|Rubricated text immediately above image: Incipit liber afforismorum ypocrati.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts]. [ca. 1250] DeRicci/Bond & Faye [78] fol. 15v
Relation.isPartOf: Hippocrates. Aphorisms.|~|Kraus. Catalogue 126, p. 19.

Subject: Authorial portraits - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Hippocrates|~|Historiated initials - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Teaching|~|Teachers
Title: Authorial portrait, Hippocrates making teaching gesture.
Description.abstract: In sharp initial "M" of "Mutationes," a lecturer located at center l. of text, (Hippocrates?), sits facing forward, holding up index finger of r. hand for emphasis.  He wears a blue gown with red robe on his lap.  Adjacent text:  Hippocrates' Aphorismi.
Description.note: Oxford, England, ca. 1250.|~|Attributed to the artist associated with William de Brailes in the Cockerell psalter.|~|Caption: Incipit particula tertia; Mutationes temporum maxime gunirare(?) morbos.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts]. [ca. 1250] DeRicci/Bond & Faye [78] fol. 19v
Relation.isPartOf: Hippocrates. Aphorisms.|~|Kraus. Catalogue 126, p. 19.

Subject: Pregnancy|~|Historiated initials - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Pregnant women
Title: Pregnant woman with hand on abdomen.
Description.abstract: In initial "P" of "Pregnantes," 3/4 length figure of woman in red gown, white mantle, white wimple and crown (?) faces r., places l. hand on womb, and raises r. hand in gesture.  Initial appears in text of Hippocrates's Aphorisms, on the first page of Book 4.  Dimensions of initial containing image: 60 x 25 mm.
Description.note: Oxford, England, ca. 1250.|~|Text to r. of image: Incipit particula prima. Pregnantes si convenit purgare ...|~|Attributed to the artist associated with William de Brailes in the Cockerell psalter.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts]. [ca. 1250] DeRicci/Bond & Faye [78] fol. 21v
Relation.isPartOf: Hippocrates. Aphorisms.|~|Kraus. Catalogue 126, p. 20.

Subject: Authorial portraits - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Hippocrates|~|Historiated initials - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Teaching|~|Teachers
Title: Authorial portrait, Hippocrates, seated, points downward.
Description.abstract: In initial "S" of "spasmus," located at center l. of text, a seated man, perhaps Hippocrates, tonsured, bearded, wears white tunic and a red cape with clusters of white spots, faces r. with arms crossed over his lap, points downward with r. hand making a gesture of instruction or command. Adjacent text: HIppocrates' Aphorismi.
Description.note: Oxford, England, ca. 1250.|~|Attributed to the artist associated with William de Brailes in the Cockerell psalter.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts]. [ca. 1250] DeRicci/Bond & Faye [78] fol. 25
Relation.isPartOf: Hippocrates. Aphorisms.|~|Kraus. Catalogue 126, p. 19.

Subject: Books|~|Physicians|~|Beds|~|Patients|~|Historiated initials - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Physician-Patient Relations
Title: Physician, perhaps Hippocrates, instructs patient.
Description.abstract: In initial "O" of "Omnis," physician, l., in 3/4 view, tonsured, bearded, wears cape and tunic, stands behind bed, holds open a book in l. hand, makes touching gesture toward patient with r. hand.  Patient, r., reclining on bed with raised back, facing l., resting head in l. hand, resting r. hand across stomach, covered with blanket from stomach to foot. Adjacent text: Hippocrates' Prognostics.
Description.note: Oxford, England, ca. 1250.|~|Attributed to the artist associated with William de Brailes in the Cockerell psalter.|~|Rubricated text immediately preceding image: Explicit liber afforismorum ypocrati; Incipit liber prognosticorum eidem.|~|Text immediately to the right of image: Omnis qui medicine artis studio sue gloriam delectabilem amicorum ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts]. [ca. 1250] DeRicci/Bond & Faye [78] fol. 32
Relation.isPartOf: Hippocrates. Prognostics.|~|IMMI Newsletter, March 1990, p. 7.|~|Tunis, E.  Early western manuscripts in the National Library of Medicine, back cover.|~|Kraus. Catalogue 126, p. 19.

Subject: Books|~|Authorial portraits - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Students|~|Hippocrates|~|Historiated initials - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Teaching|~|Teachers
Title: Teacher, perhaps Hippocrates, instructs student.
Description.abstract: At center l. of text, in initial "O" of "Oportet," physician (Hippocrates?), seated at r., faces l., wears white tunic with a red cape covering his right arm, makes teaching gesture with l. hand, holds book with r. Student, l., wears blue tunic with a blue cape covering his l. arm, makes questioning gesture with r. hand, holds book with l. Student wears blue gown, teacher wears white gown with blue robe. Adjacent text: Hippocrates' Prognostics.
Description.note: Oxford, England, ca. 1250.|~|Attributed to the artist associated with William de Brailes in the Cockerell psalter.|~|Rubricated text above image: Incipit prima particula huius libri. Oportet ergo de sollicitum circa acutas valetudines.|~|Text immediately to the right of image: Oportet ergo te sollicitum circa acutas valetudines.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts]. [ca. 1250] DeRicci/Bond & Faye [78] fol. 32v
Relation.isPartOf: Hippocrates. Prognostics.|~|Kraus. Catalogue 126, p. 19.

Subject: Books|~|Physicians|~|Urine Flasks|~|Historiated initials - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Uroscopy
Title: Seated physician, perhaps Theophilus, performs uroscopy, discourses.
Description.abstract: In initial "D" of "De", physician (Theophilus Protospatharius?), tonsured, bearded, wearing red cloak and green gown, sits on red and tan bench, faces r. in 3/4 view, makes teaching gesture with r. hand and pointing finger while holding blue uroscopy flask in l. hand. To r., book, held open over bench (by unseen stand?), and balanced on lower r. corner, displays writing not resembling latin script, attempting to suggest Greek? Adjacent text: Theophilos Protospatharios' De urinis.
Description.note: Oxford, England, ca. 1250.|~|Attributed to the artist associated with William de Brailes in the Cockerell psalter.|~|Rubricated text immediately preceding image: Incipit liber urinarum.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts]. [ca. 1250] DeRicci/Bond & Faye [78] fol. 35
Relation.isPartOf: Theophilos Protospatharios, 7th cent. De urinis.|~|Kraus.  Catalogue 126, p. 20.|~|Tunis, E.  Early western manuscripts in the National Library of Medicine, front cover.|~|Kraus. Catalogue 126, p. 19.

Subject: Geometrical Diagrams - Danube River Valley - 1276-1350|~|Authorial portraits - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Physicians|~|Students|~|Theophilos Protospatharios, 7th cent.|~|Urine Flasks|~|Historiated initials - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Uroscopy
Title: Physician performs uroscopy before observer.
Description.abstract: In the initial "U" of "Urina", located at bottom l. of text, a medical lecturer (Theophilus?) holds up a blue urine flask in his r. hand.  He wears a red gown with a white robe.  At l., a student in green gown and red robe observes him.  Adjacent text: Theophilus Protospatharius's De urinis.
Description.note: Oxford, England, ca. 1250.|~|Attributed to the artist associated with William de Brailes in the Cockerell psalter.|~|Text immediately to r. of image: Urina ergo est colamentum ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts]. [ca. 1250] DeRicci/Bond & Faye [78] fol. 42v
Relation.isPartOf: Theophilos Protospatharios, 7th cent. De urinis.|~|Kraus. Catalogue 126, p. 19.

Subject: Authorial portraits - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Physicians|~|Students|~|Theophilos Protospatharios, 7th cent.|~|Historiated initials - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Teaching|~|Teachers
Title: Physician and student converse.
Description.abstract: In initial "O" of "Omnis," located at centerl. of text, sit two men. The man on the l. (Theophilus?) wearing a white gown, blue robe, and a cap, makes an emphatic gesture with his r. hand.  The student on the r. , in red gown and blue robe, makes a questioning gesture.  Adjacent text: Theophilus Protospatharius's De Urinis.
Description.note: Oxford, England, ca. 1250.|~|Attributed to the artist associated with William de Brailes in the Cockerell psalter.|~|Text to immediate r. of image: Omnis ydropsis in acuta ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts]. [ca. 1250] DeRicci/Bond & Faye [78] fol. 43
Relation.isPartOf: Theophilos Protospatharios, 7th cent. De urinis.|~|Kraus. Catalogue 126, p. 19.

Subject: Authorial portraits - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Galen|~|Students|~|Historiated initials - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Teaching|~|Teachers
Title: Physician, perhaps Galen, instructs students.
Description.abstract: In the inital rounded "T" of "Tres," located at top l. of text, a teacher (Galen?) seated in a white chair at l. lectures to three students at r.  The teacher wears a green gown and red robe.  Adjacent text: Galenis Microtegni.
Description.note: Oxford, England, ca. 1250.|~|Attributed to the artist associated with William de Brailes in the Cockerell psalter.|~|Rubricated text preceding image: Hic incipit Tegni Galieni.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts]. [ca. 1250] DeRicci/Bond & Faye [78] fol. 61
Relation.isPartOf: Galen. Techne iatrike.|~|Kraus. Catalogue 126, p. 19.

Subject: Books|~|Authorial portraits - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Galen|~|Physicians|~|Students|~|Historiated initials - England - Oxford - 1250|~|Teaching|~|Teachers
Title: Physician, perhaps Galen, seated in initial M, instructs students.
Description.abstract: In the initial "M" of "Medicina," at center l. of text, a teacher (Galen?) is seated atop the sharp central V of the letter, lecturing to students at either side of him.  The teacher wears a red gown and blue robe, and holds an open book in l. hand.  He looks toward student at l., who wears green gown and red robe, but he points with r. hand to student at r., in white gown.  Adjacent text: Galen's Microtegni.
Description.note: Oxford, England, ca. 1250.|~|Attributed to the artist associated with William de Brailes in the Cockerell psalter.|~|Rubricated text preceding image: Diffiniti medicine.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts]. [ca. 1250] DeRicci/Bond & Faye [78] fol. 61v
Relation.isPartOf: Galen. Techne iatrike.|~|Kraus. Catalogue 126, p. 19.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Plants, Medicinal|~|Compositae|~|Ranunculaceae|~|Flowers
Title: Materia medica, probably herb Nigella.
Description.abstract: In the upper l. margin, rudimentary sketch of a medical simple apparently intended to treat stones: a four-petalled flower at the top of a slender stem, with two linear leaves and one pendent opening bud growing from the lower leaf axil. The sketch is probably intended to represent a species of Nigella (family Ranunculaceae).  It might possibly be intended to represent a species of Conyza (family Compositae). Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: Heading preceding image: Lapis in vesica ...|~|Text to the right of image: Coniza stranguriam ... cioniza ... Nigello ... Nigella ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 50v [i.e. 10v]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Leaves|~|Plants, Medicinal|~|Astringents|~|Acorns|~|Hand|~|Fagaceae
Title: Pointing hand and materia medica, a stylized oak sprig.
Description.abstract: In upper r. margin, a pointing hand indicating text on the medicinal use of acorns (glandes), and below, a rudimentary stylized sketch of a long elliptical oak (family Fagaceae, Quercus, sp.) leaf with scalloped edges, its stem and central spine placed vertically and two acorns drooping from peduncles attached to the stem.  Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works. Dimensions of image: 25 x 30 mm.
Description.note: Text to left of hand image: secundum Alexandrum quod glans est ita stiptica ...|~|Text to left of second image: glandi in potus sumptus decocqui in aqua ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 51v [i.e. fol. 11]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Blood Vessels|~|Blood Coagulation
Title: Blood vessels.
Description.abstract: In center r. margin, a heart-shaped bag with an unfastened tube on top, another tube dangling; at the top of the lower tube, a valve-like structure.  It is apparently meant to represent an anatomical structure, possibly part of the blood system, or a vesicle, perhaps the seminal vesicle.  Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: England, ca. 1400.|~|Text preceding image: Sanguis coagulatur in vesica si in aliquis partibus hunc dabis pulverem qui liquefacit sanguinem ...|~|Text in margin above image: stiptica et restrictiva.|~|Text to immediate left of image: cum lacto ... ut potest modo fieri emplastrum ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 52 [i.e. fol. 12]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Coitus|~|Genitalia, Male|~|Genitalia, Female|~|Uterus
Title: Diagram of genitals in sexual intercourse, including seven-chambered womb.
Description.abstract: In upper r. margin, a detailed but stylized captioned drawing of testicles, and of penis being inserted into a vulva atop a seven-chambered uterus. Composition is vertical, penis at top, uterus at bottom. Numbers inscribed in segments of uterus: 6,4,2,1,3,5,7. Inscribed in central segment ("1"): Matrix.  Dimensions of image: 90 x 35 mm.  Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: Chapter heading preceding image on fol. 12: Virga virilis.|~|Caption above image: testiculi.|~|Caption surrounding upper part of image: membra virilia.|~|Caption to right of image: Vulva.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 53 [i.e. fol. 13]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Leaves|~|Oxalidaceae|~|Plants, Medicinal
Title: Corosona herba.
Description.abstract: In upper l. margin, the outline of a trifoliate compound leaf with two lobes on each leaf, representing "Corosona" (family Oxalidaceae), probably Oxalis sp., perhaps O. acetosella (Common Wood Sorrel), used to cleanse dead or excess flesh around ulcers. Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: Text to right of image: Corosona prima ad mundificandi[sic] carnem mortuum vel superfluam in ulcere ... hec herba non habet nisi tria folia in singulis ... et habet radices rubeas et est herba valde acida ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica]. fol. 53v [i.e. 13v]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Syringes|~|Surgical Instruments
Title: Instrument, perhaps syringe, hollow needle or probe.
Description.abstract: In lower l. margin, rudimentary sketch of a medical instrument, probably a syringe, perhaps a hollow needle or probe: a long vertical rod or tube with a small bulb at the top and a flared, open bottom, shows a smaller rod protruding at the bottom, ending in a rectangular handle (plunger of syringe?).  Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.  Dimensions of image: 70 x 15 mm.
Description.note: England, ca. 1400].
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 41v [i.e. fol. 1v]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica|~|http://ihm.nlm.nih.gov/luna/servlet/view/search?q=A027180

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Plants, Medicinal|~|Umbelliferae|~|Greens, Edible
Title: Petrosilinum vel persil, materia medica.
Description.abstract: At top r. margin of leaf, a rudimentary sketch of a parsley plant, Petroselinum crispum, Umbelliferae (Dill Family).  Leaves, deeply dissected, arranged nearly opposite on a single stem.  Three-lobed structure at top of stem, perhaps to represent the inflorescence,  the umbel-shaped flowering structure.  Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: England, ca. 1400.|~|Text at top l. of page, with decorated initial and larger script: Petrosilinum vel persil est de petra et sileo ... quasi petram in vesica perforans ...|~|Caption beneath sketch (highly abbreviated): petrosil.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 66 [i.e. 26]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.|~|http://ihm.nlm.nih.gov/luna/servlet/view/search?q=A027173

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Liliaceae|~|Plants, Medicinal
Title: Materia medica, aloe.
Description.abstract: In low r. margin, rudimentary sketch of a plant, used for making wound unguent, with leaves that are arranged oppositely on a single stem. The leaves are all three-lobed and end in sharp points. The stem ends in a three-pointed structure at the top. It is apparently intended to represent aloe (family Liliaceae), Aloe sp., perhaps A. vera (Medicinal Aloe, Barbados Aloe). Adjacent text: John of Arderne's excerpted works. Dimensions of image 30 x 35 mm.
Description.note: Chapter heading preceding image: Unguentum viride valens ad plagas veteras ...|~|Text to l. of image: de pulvere aloes subtilissimo ... aloes in dicto unguento ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 68 [i.e. fol. 28]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Fissure in ano|~|Rectal Fistula - surgery
Title: Details of operations for fistula in ano.
Description.abstract: Operating procedures. In the upper l. margin, a set of three rudimentary sketches: the first drawing is in the form of a 6-armed jagged star, intended to represent a perforated rectum ("longaon"). The second resembles a quarter moon facing upwards, intended to represent the fallen follicle of a testicle. The third is a narrow rod with circular structures in the middle, or needle passing through the dark spot in the center of a double circle and passing out below, apparently from beneath the inner circle and over the outer ring, intended to represent a fistula in a rectum ("longaon") or penis. Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 40v [i.e. fol. 30v]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Patients|~|Rectal Fistula - surgery
Title: Patient prepared for fistula in ano operation. Set of small sketches on surgical technique.
Description.abstract: Between blocks of text in the center of the page, a rudimentary sketch of a male patient prostrate on stomach, head on pillow, r., robe or sheet covering back, nates exposed, showing fistulae, and penis and testicles stretched back. In margin to r., below, a set of three small rudimentary images, arranged vertically, illustrating procedures for rectal surgery. Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: Text following first image: Tunc primo impellat medicus digitum manus ... oleo vel aliquo unguento in unctu in ano ...|~|Text to the left of the set of small images: Si plurima fuerunt foramina sicut ad hoc signum depingitur et aliquanter temptet super digitum in ano...Accipint medicus acum fol.73v, [i.e.33v] rostratam et caput oculum habens per foramen lure propinquius impellat digito sinistro in anum...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 73 [i.e. fol. 33]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Surgical Instruments|~|Rectal Fistula - surgery
Title: Rectum and razor for operation on fistula in ano.
Description.abstract: In the lower r. margin, a very rudimentary sketch of a rectum and a scalpel or razor to be used for an operation on fistula in ano. Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: Folio 33v Caption: Protractis ....|~|Text to immediate left of image: ponat medicus punctum rasorii in concavitate ... sicut ad tale signum depingitur.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 74 [i.e. fol. 34]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Bandages
Title: Bandaging for a wound.
Description.abstract: In the middle r. margin: a faint rudimentary sketch apparently intended to demonstrate bandaging techniques. Parallel lines in a criss-cross pattern form a rough cylinder, with two strips emerging from the top, forming a "V" shape. Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: Text to immediate left of image: drapella linea ... in latitudine septum vel octo ... in longitudine tandem ut plaga ad modum sicut hic depingitur ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 75 [i.e. fol. 35]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Rectal Fistula - surgery
Title: Schematic diagram of clinical procedure for fistula.
Description.abstract: Rudimentary sketch in upper rt. margin, apparently intended to show a procedure for removing a fistula with a cord or knot: from top to bottom, two parallel lines, two rough circles, the first perhaps intended to show a bowl or concave shape, and an oval or vertical ellipse, with curved lines extending from a horizontal line above its center. The curves extend away to the left and right. Adjacent text: John Arderne'sexcerpted works.
Description.note: Text to the left of image: posset dissolvi sine instrumento et cum nodo ... sicut hic depingitur ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 77 [i.e. fol. 37]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Rectal Fistula|~|Plants, Medicinal|~|Compositae|~|Leg
Title: Materia medica. Fistula in ano.
Description.abstract: One medicinal plant in margin, upper l., one partial human figure in a space between blocks of text, center r., both sketches very rudimentary.  An outline of a plant with odd-pinnate leaves, intended to represent a materia medica used in a recipe for the treatment of multiple fistulas, perhaps Artemisia absinthium (Wormwood, family Compositae).  One pair of legs extending to the r. from a torso. Representation of a large swollen fistula in the lower r. buttock.  Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: Text immediately preceding image: Si fuerint vero plura foramina sicut hic depingitur ad invice in perforatur tunc debet medicus ...|~|Text to right of first image: Recepit Ari, Absinchii, Capsiniobusae, ebuli ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 78v [i.e. fol. 38v]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Body, Human|~|Leg
Title: Partial human figure, torso and legs.
Description.abstract: In upper r. side, in space between blocks of text, rudimentary sketch of one partial human torso with legs and feet extending to r. Adjacent text: John of Arderne's Treatises of fistula in ano.  For the text in a Middle English translation, see Power, EETS no. 139, 1910, p. 32. Dimensions of image: 20 x 15 mm.
Description.note: Chapter heading preceding image: Vidi unum hominem de Northampton qui habuit tria foramina in nate sinistra et tria in folliculo testiculorum ...|~|Text to left of image: de incisione Vero longaonis sanguis fortiter emanit quia fistula fuerat valde profunda ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 79 [i.e. fol. 39]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Rectal Fistula|~|Illustrations - England - 1400
Title: Partial figures showing legs with fistulae. Similar figure.
Description.abstract: Two rudimentary sketches in spaces between blocks of text, upper and lower r.: two figures showing torso with legs and feet extending to the right. Representation of a fistula on r. buttock of both figures. Adjacent text: John of Arderne's Treatises of fistula in ano. For the text in Middle English translation, see Power, EETS no. 139, 1910, p. 33. Dimensions of both images: 30 x 60 mm.
Description.note: Caption: ... duo foramina; ... octo foramina.|~|Text preceding first image: Sed quia orificium ulceris fuerat minis strictum primum supraposui de unguento ruptorio de calce viva et sapone ad orificium fistule enlargandum ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 79v [i.e. fol. 39v]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Distillation apparatus
Title: Apparatus, perhaps a still.
Description.abstract: Rudimentary sketch of an apparatus, perhaps a still; a circle with parallel lines extending straight above to the left, straight down, just to the right and with lower branching at perpendicular angles. Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 81 [i.e. 41]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Rectal Diseases - therapy
Title: Treatment of rectal cancer.
Description.abstract: In the lower r. of page, between blocks of text, partial human figure: rudimentary sketch of a lower torso, and two legs extending to the r., with indications of very large swellings intended to represent cancers of the rectum, and depiction of a finger or instrument being placed between the buttocks, perhaps applying medication. Adjacent text: John of Arderne's Treatises of fistula in ano. For the text in Middle English translation, see Power, EETS 139, 1910, p. 39. Dimensions of image: 25 x 65 mm.
Description.note: Text preceding image, on fol. 41v: Bubo est apostema infra anum in longaone nascens ...|~|Text to immediate left of image: Vidi etiam aliquos habentes ardorem vehementissimum circa anum exterius et pruruginem intolerabilem cum cutis corrugationem circa anum ad modum burse concluse sicut hic depingitur ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 83 [i.e. fol. 43]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Rectal Fistula|~|Illustrations - England - 1400
Title: Figure showing torso and legs.  Similar figure showing eight deep fistulae.
Description.abstract: Two rudimentary sketches of human figures in spaces between blocks of text, upper right, lower right, with legs and feet extending to the right from a section of torso. The lower sketch shows five very deep fistulae in the nates, two in the left buttock and three in the right buttock. The penis hangs between the legs. Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: Chapter heading above second image: Quondam habuit super nates ficum ... sanquinem emittentem.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 84v [i.e. fol. 44v]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Plants, Medicinal
Title: Materia medica.
Description.abstract: In the upper r. margin, a plant with a curving stem and with elliptic, widely dentate leaves opposite each other, and ending with a leaf at the top of the stem. Adjecent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: Chapter heading preceding image, on fol. 55: Extracta emoroidarum secundum lanfrancum ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 56
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Leg|~|Drainage
Title: Draining lesion, wound or incision in ankle.
Description.abstract: In the lower l. margin: Rudimentary sketch of a lower leg (calf to feet) with fluid (perhaps blood) draining into a bowl from an incision near the joint between the foot and the ankle. JOhn of Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: Chapter heading above image: Contingenti ... superfluo expediet ...|~|Text in margin, perhaps a later hand: Modus purgandi.
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 102v [i.e. fol. 58v]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Marginalia - England - 1400|~|Syringes|~|Surgical Instruments|~|Cautery - instrumentation
Title: Cauterizing instrument, an iron or syringe.
Description.abstract: In center l. margin: a tube or rod with  a slightly bulbous top and a somewhat flared bottom.  A thinner rod (plunger or handle?) emerges from the flared base, ending in a ring or a disk with a concave depression. Dimensions of image: 50 x 10 mm. Adjacent text: John Arderne's excerpted works.
Description.note: Caption in margn above image, perhaps in a later hand: Cauterizantio sive corrosiva ...|~|Text preceding image: Medicina cauterizante ut est urticolum combustum ... vel cum calce vina mixtum in casu magno hoc est in magna corrosione longaonis ...
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica] fol. 104v [i.e. fol. 60v]
Relation.isPartOf: Arderne, John, fl. 1307-1370. Opera chirurgica.

Subject: Ear|~|Monks|~|Tongue|~|Brain|~|Head|~|Nose
Title: Diagram of brain function.
Description.abstract: Diagram in the form of a rudely drawn human head, with friar's tonsure and hooded habit faces l., with tongue protruding, sense organs and supposed locations of mental functions all labelled.  Labels are written on representations of elaborately folded ribbons joined with lines to precise spots on the face and skull. A spot on  the l. forehead is labelled "organum virtutis imaginative," one on the r. forehead "organum sensus communis," one on the vertex  "organum virtutis cogitative," one on the occiput "organum virtutis memorative." Above a decorative base another folded banner identifies the author "...item per me fratrum silvestrum coadiaconum ordo fratrum predicatorum filium conventus franckfordensis facta est hec ymago anno salutifere incarnacionis domini 1497." For full transcription of captions, see Sigerist, 1943. Adjacent text: commentary on Aristotle's De Anima.
Description.note: Cologne, 1497.|~|Signed by one "frater silvester coci", that is, Brother Silvester Koch, or "Brother Silvester son of Cook."
Source: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Incunabula. Schullian 274 (Copulator super tres libros Aristotelis. De anima doctrinam Thomae de Aquino) fol. 105v
Relation.isPartOf: Sigerist, H. "Two Fifteeth-century anatomical Drawings," BHM 13, 1943, p. 315.|~|Clarke and Dewhurst, Illustrated History of Brain Function, 1971, p. 17.|~|Sigerist, H. "Two Fifteeth-century anatomical Drawings," BHM 13, 1943, pp. 313-316.|~|Clarke and Dewhurst. Illustrated History of Brain Function, p. 17.|~|http://ihm.nlm.nih.gov/luna/servlet/view/search?q=A012030

Subject: Ear|~|Heart|~|Tongue|~|Trachea|~|Stomach|~|Brain - physiology|~|Head|~|Alimentary canal|~|Skull|~|Liver|~|Nose|~|Spleen|~|Diagrams - Germany - Cologne - 1500
Title: Diagram of brain functions.
Description.abstract: In printed book, a hand-drawn combination of figure and diagram: Precisely shaded drawing of human head facing l., emphasizing external facial structure.  On hairless skull, four labels inscribed on circles: on forehead, Sensus communis; just behind forehead, Virtus imaginativa; on vertex, Virtus cogitativa; on occiput, Memoria.  Labels on face: between eyes, Visus cuius obiectum est color; beside ear, Auditus cuius obiectum est...; below nose, Olfactus cuius obiectum est odor; on tongue, Gustus cuius obiectum est gustabile.  On back of neck: Tactus.  Below neck, rudimentary diagram of vital organs.  Alimentary canal leads straight down to oval labelled Stomachus.  Windpipe branches above to l. leading above to small, double-lobed Pulmo connected by a passage leading r. to heart, labelled Cor, in turn connected to liver directly beneath it labelled Epar, in turn joined to stomach at r.  Unconnected, irregularly shaped organ at l. labelled Splen. For full transcription of captions, see Sigerist, 1943.
Description.note: Cologne, ca. 1500.|~|Caption: Voluntas, intellectus possibilis, intellectus agens.
Source: National Library of Medicine  (U.S.). Incunabula. Schullian 379 (Positiones circa libros Physicorum et De anima Aristotelis) fol. 47v
Relation.isPartOf: Clarke and Dewhurst, Illustrated History of Brain Function, 1971, p. 24.|~|Sigerist, H., "Two Fifteeth-century anatomical Drawings," BHM 13, 1943, p. 317.|~|Schullian and Sommer, Catalogue of incunabula ... in the Army Medical Library, 1950, plate 6, facing p. 168.|~|Sigerist, H. "Two Fifteeth-century anatomical Drawings," BHM 13, 1943, pp. 318-319.|~|Clarke and Dewhurst. Illustrated History of Brain Function, p. 24.|~|http://ihm.nlm.nih.gov/luna/servlet/view/search?q=A012031

Subject: Body, Human|~|Illustrations - England - York - 1364|~|Bloodletting figures - England - York - 1364
Title: Bloodletting figure or phlebotomy man.
Description.abstract: One diagrammatic human figure on points for bloodletting, labeled "Imago phlebotomiae." A rudimentary figure, male, outlined in black, hair colored brown, lips and cheeks red.  Face, torso, hands and feet detailed in black ink.  15 circles surround the figure, each containing the names of particular veins in black and/or red ink, one in black.  Each circle or "balloon" also mentions the condition or disease which calls for bloodletting at that sight. A red line joins each "balloon" to the site of the respective vein. Adj. text: 14th century physician's belt book in Latin.
Description.note: England, York, 1364
Source: Rosenbach Museum and Library. Manuscript. Rosenbach 1004/29. [Physician's belt book] fol. 8
Relation.isPartOf: Sixty Bokes Olde and Newe, David Anderson, ed. New Chaucer Society, 1986, pp. 92-95.

Subject: Prognosis|~|Urine Flasks|~|Circular diagrams - England - York - 1364|~|Illustrations - England - York - 1364
Title: Urine Wheel, complete.
Description.abstract: One circular diagram or "color wheel" for uroscopy, labeled "Tabula urinarum," showing 20 jordans or urine flasks containing urines of various colors indicating different states of "digestion" (in the understanding of humoral physiology). Each flask is attached by a line to a balloon of text inscribed with a summary of the state of digestion and often the prognosis. The captions of the two flasks which face each other at 12 o'clock, for example, read "reddish color of urine, or beautiful gold" and "pinkish color of urine, or oriental crocus." The "balloon" to which the left flask is attached reads "These two urines signify completion of digestion, while the right one belongs to a group linked to a "balloon" reading "these four urines signify exessive digestion."  In contrast to these relatively favorable prognoses, the dark colored jordans at five o'clock are linked to a balloon reading, "these urines signify death."  Adj. text: 14th century physician's belt book in Latin.
Description.note: England, York, 1364
Source: Rosenbach Museum and Library. Manuscript. Rosenbach 1004/29. [Physician's belt book] fol. 9
Relation.isPartOf: Sixty Bokes Olde and Newe, David Anderson, ed. New Chaucer Society, 1986, pp. 92-95.

Subject: Physicians|~|Students|~|Urine Flasks|~|Teaching|~|Teachers|~|Uroscopy|~|Historiated initials - France - Paris - 1301-1325
Title: Urine flask, in teaching scene.
Description.abstract: In decorated initial "D," beige, inscr. in blue square with illuminated border, continuous with foliated text bracket;  inscr. in "D," teacher (physician?), l., in blue cap and hooded gown, with orange shirt, on orange-cushioned chair, facing r., holding up urine flask, green, in r. hand, l. hand on knee; 4 students, opp., tonsured, front one in orange hooded gown, blue shirt, front 2 students gesticulating with r. hands; entire background illuminated. Adjacent text: Bernard of Gordon, Tractatus de conservatione vitae Humanae.
Description.note: France, perhaps Paris, 1311-1325.
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Manuscript. Benjamin Collection 3. [Single leaf from Bernard of Gordon's Tractatus de conservatione vitae humanae]. [1311-1325?]  fol. 1
Relation.isPartOf: Bernard, de Gordon, ca. 1260 - ca. 1318. Liber de conservatione vitae humanae.|~|O'Malley & Gnudi.  Benjamin collection, p. 3

Subject: Illustrations - Germany - 1350|~|Urine Flasks
Title: Urine flasks, in text.
Description.abstract: Three urine flasks, roughly sketched, no color differentiation, in midst of German text (same as Benj. MS 11, 249v-258r).  Similarly, on 7v, 8r (5 flasks), 8v (2 flasks), 9r (7 flasks), 9v, 10r, 10v, 11r, 11v.
Description.note: Germany, ca. 1350.
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Manuscript. Benjamin Collection 5. [Fuer das Urin oder Stein]. [ca. 1350] Benjamin Ms. 3 fol. 2v
Relation.isPartOf: O'Malley & Gnudi.  Benjamin collection, p.3

Subject: Color|~|Diagrams - Germany - 1350|~|Prognosis|~|Urine Flasks
Title: Urine flasks, in text. Page 1
Description.abstract: Diagram or color wheel of 20 urine flasks (XIV c.?), with peripheral Latin captions describing color, cut into 15 pieces and pasted in as illustration to German text (same text as Benj. MS 11, 249v-258r).  10 face clockwise, 10 counterclockwise.  Color order: red, gray, yellow, green, blue, brown.  Small inner wheels with group caption indicating prognosis pasted beside each wheel section.  All circles outlined in light green.  Crimson lines that originally linked inner wheels to individual flasks quite visible.
Description.note: Germany, ca. 1500
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Manuscript. Benjamin Collection 5. [Fuer das Urin oder Stein]. [ca. 1350] Benjamin Ms. 3 fol. 3-5
Relation.isPartOf: O'Malley & Gnudi.  Benjamin collection, p. 3

Subject: Color|~|Diagrams - Germany - 1350|~|Prognosis|~|Urine Flasks
Title: Urine flasks, in text. Page 4
Description.abstract: Diagram or color wheel of 20 urine flasks (XIV c.?), with peripheral Latin captions describing color, cut into 15 pieces and pasted in as illustration to German text (same text as Benj. MS 11, 249v-258r).  10 face clockwise, 10 counterclockwise.  Color order: red, gray, yellow, green, blue, brown.  Small inner wheels with group caption indicating prognosis pasted beside each wheel section.  All circles outlined in light green.  Crimson lines that originally linked inner wheels to individual flasks quite visible.
Description.note: Germany, ca. 1500
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Manuscript. Benjamin Collection 5. [Fuer das Urin oder Stein]. [ca. 1350] Benjamin Ms. 3 fol. 3-5
Relation.isPartOf: O'Malley & Gnudi.  Benjamin collection, p. 3

Subject: Illustrations - Germany - 1350|~|Urine Flasks
Title: Urine flasks, in text.
Description.abstract: Three urine flasks, roughly sketched, partly over German text (same text as Benj. MS 11, 249v-258r).  Red mark at lip of r. flask, with attempt to represent floating matter (?).  Red mark at lip and liquid level of 2nd flask, with attempt to represent floating matter and precipitate (?).  2nd flask, r. flask, red mark at lip with attempt to represent floating matter on yellow-brown urine (?).
Description.note: Germany, ca. 1350.
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Manuscript. Benjamin Collection 5. [Fuer das Urin oder Stein]. [ca. 1350] Benjamin Ms. 3 fol. 5v
Relation.isPartOf: O'Malley & Gnudi.  Benjamin collection, p.3

Subject: Illustrations - Czechoslovakia - Prague - 1450|~|Zodiac|~|Body, Human|~|Bloodletting - charts|~|Bloodletting figures - Czechoslovakia - Prague - 1450
Title: Bloodletting figure, male.
Description.abstract: Bloodletting figure, male, in ink, mostly outline.  Some detailing of hand, ribs, genitals, toes.  Parts labelled with relevant signs of the zodiac.  Veins and joints noted.  Some rubrication.
Description.note: Czechoslovakia (Prague?) middle of the fifteenth century.
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Manuscript. Benjamin Collection 10 [Medical collectanea, 2] fol. 90
Relation.isPartOf: Ferrari, M.  Medieval and Renaissance manuscripts at the University of California, Los Angeles, p. 30.|~|O'Malley & Gnudi.  Benjamin collection, p. 4.

Subject: Body, Human|~|Disease figures - Czechoslovakia - Prague - 1450|~|Disease - charts
Title: Male disease figure. Page 2
Description.abstract: Disease figure, male, simply drawn, spread across five pages: upper body (heart and above) on fol. 91, l. arm on 91v, r. arm on 90v.  Figure bearded, arms outspread, palms forward, some exterior detail of hair, neck, nipples, pectorals, lateral muscles.  Lower torso (lungs to genitals) appears on fol. 92. Large structure above genitals.  Legs (thighs to toes) appear on fol. 92v.  Extensive captioning of diseases afflicting each part.  Some general anatomical terms included.  Diagram and captions rubricated.
Description.note: Czechoslovakia (Prague?), mid-fifteenth century.
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Manuscript. Benjamin Collection 10 [Medical collectanea, 2] fol. 90v-92v.
Relation.isPartOf: IMMI newsletter, v. 1, no. 2 (June 1989), cover.|~|Layne, S.S. Medieval and Renaissance manuscripts at the University of California, Los Angeles, p. 30|~|O'Malley & Gnudi.  Benjamin collection, p. 4.

Subject: Illustrations - Czechoslovakia - Prague - 1450|~|Urine Flasks
Title: Urine flasks, in text.
Description.abstract: Rough attempts to sketch urine flasks to accompany text likely copied from a standard urine color wheel (Iste due urine signat perfectionem digestionis...).  Attempt abandoned after this page, though text continues for several pages.
Description.note: Czechoslovakia (Prague?), mid-fifteenth century.
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Manuscript. Benjamin Collection 10 [Medical collectanea, 2] fol. 94

Subject: Boys|~|Jesus Christ|~|Illustrations - Armenia - 1301-1325|~|Epilepsy
Title: Christ's Cure of an epileptic boy.
Description.abstract: One image on bottom half of folio, Christ, nimbed, wears robes and is seated l., against a panel of gold, addresses the father of the epileptic, pointing with two fingers of his r. hand towards the epileptic while holding a scroll on his lap with his l. hand. The father of the epileptic kneels at the r. and points both his index fingers towards his son (or Christ?). The boy, center, is shown contorted, his arms outstretched over his head which is turned up while he is bent over at the waist balanced on his r. leg as his l. leg protrudes back and bent at the knee. He wears loose white clothing with a chain around his waist, a reference to their inability to restrain him from throwing himself into fire and water (Matt. 17:15).  The miniature is marred by a diagonal scratch and a fold. Image occupies bottom 1/3 of page. Adjacent text: The Gospel of Matthew, in Armenian, commisioned by abbot Esayi Ncéeci.
Description.note: Glajor, Armenia, first quarter of the fourteenth century (ca. 1300-1307).|~|Attributed to: "The Third Painter of the Glajor Gospels."
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Manuscript. Arm. Ms.1 [Glajor Gospel]  p. 108
Relation.isPartOf: Bible. N.T. Gospels. Armenian. Gladzori Avetaran.|~|Mathews & Sanjian.  Armenian gospel iconography, repr. pl. 27, disc., p. 98.

Subject: Jesus Christ|~|Illustrations - Armenia - 1301-1325|~|Blindness
Title: Christ's Cure of the Blind in Jericho.
Description.abstract: One image occupying bottom half of folio: Christ and two disciples, nimbed, stand l. with Christ making blessing gesture towards two blind men seated r., with two fingers of his r. hand and holding a scroll in his l. The two blind men, bearded, with eyes tightly closed, each hold light-colored canes with both hands and each wears a purse slung over the r. shoulder and chest to their l. sides.  The background distinguishes Christ's world with a panel of gold from the world of the blind men, a cityscape. Adjacent text: Gospel of Matthew in Armenian, comissioned by abbot Esayi Ncé°ec°i.
Description.note: Glajor, Armenia, first quarter of the fourteenth century (ca. 1300-1307).|~|Attributed to: "The Fourth Painter of the Glajor Gospels."
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Manuscript. Arm. Ms.1 [Glajor Gospel] p. 124
Relation.isPartOf: Bible. N.T. Gospels. Armenian. Gladzori Avetaran.|~|Mathews & Sanjian.  Armenian gospel iconography, repr., pl. 30, disc., p. 101.

Subject: Jesus Christ|~|Illustrations - Armenia - 1301-1325|~|Skin Diseases|~|Lepers
Title: Christ's Cure of the Leper.
Description.abstract: One image on bottom two-thirds of folio: The leper of Mark 1:40, r., thickly covered with small lesions and clad only in a loincloth, kneels before Christ, holding his r. hand up and his l. hand out, palm up.  Four apostles, nimbed and wearing robes, stand witness behind Christ on l. Christ, also nimbed and wearing robes, reaches out with his r. hand and blesses the the leper, touching the supplicant's head with two fingers and holding a scroll in his l. hand. Gold panel(?) behind Christ and apostles on l., cityscape behind leper on r. Adjacent text: Gospel of Mark in Armenian, comissioned by abbot Esayi Ncé°ec°i.
Description.note: Glajor, Armenia, first quarter of the fourteenth century (ca. 1300-1307).|~|Attributed to: "The Fourth Painter of the Glajor Gospels."
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Manuscript. Arm. Ms.1 [Glajor Gospel]  p. 197
Relation.isPartOf: Bible. N.T. Gospels. Armenian. Gladzori Avetaran.|~|Mathews & Sanjian.  Armenian gospel iconography, repr. pl. 45 disc., p. 118.

Subject: Jesus Christ|~|Illustrations - Armenia - 1301-1325|~|Blindness
Title: Christ's Cure of the Blind Man at Bethsaida.
Description.abstract: One image covering bottom one-third of folio: Against the backdrop of the village of Bethsaida, Christ, nimbed and wearing robes, is shown leading the blind man of Mark 8:27-34 with his l. hand by holding the man's r. hand and anointing his eyes with spittle on two fingers of this r. hand.  The blind man wears a purse on a strap over his l. shoulder. Adjacent text: Gospel of Mark in Armenian, comissioned by abbot Esayi Ncé°ec°i.
Description.note: Glajor, Armenia, first quarter of the fourteenth century (ca. 1300-1307).|~|Attributed to: T°oros Taronec°i.
Source: Bible. N.T. Gospels. Armenian. Gladzori Avetaran. [Glajor Gospel]. [between 1300 and 1307] Arm. ms. 1 p. 235.
Relation.isPartOf: Mathews & Sanjian.  Armenian gospel iconography, repr. pl. 50 disc., p. 123.

Subject: Jesus Christ|~|Illustrations - Armenia - 1301-1325|~|Blindness
Title: Christ's Cure of Blind Bartimaeus.
Description.abstract: One image covering top half of folio is divided in half. Christ and Peter nimbed, stand l. against a background of gold over green. Against an ultramarine background, a young disciple r., holds his l. hand extended diagonally and with his r. hand takes the r. hand of the seated blind beggar Bartimaeus of Mark 10:46-53.  Bartimaeus holds eyes tightly closes, and wears a purse over the l. shoulder, and a hat, which is falling off his head.  Adjacent text: The Gospel of Mark in Armenian, commisioned by abbot Esayi Ncé°ec°i.
Description.note: Glajor, Armenia, first quarter of the fourteenth century (ca. 1300-1307).|~|Attributed to: T°oros Taronec°i.
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Manuscript. Arm. Ms.1 [Glajor Gospel]  p. 250
Relation.isPartOf: Bible. N.T. Gospels. Armenian. Gladzori Avetaran.|~|Mathews & Sanjian.  Armenian gospel iconography, repr. pl. 51 disc., p. 124.

Subject: Jesus Christ|~|Illustrations - Armenia - 1301-1325|~|Paralysis
Title: Christ's Cure of the Paralytic.
Description.abstract: One full-page image: Christ nimbed and wearing robes, sits l. before three disciples nimbed (only their heads are seen). Two men, l. and r. wearing robes, crouch on opposing roofs of what appear to be two buildings facing each other. They each hold ropes in both hands by which they have lowered down the sick man.  The paralytic lying on a rug-like bed supported by the two ropes before Christ in the center, gestures with both hands towards Christ, the l. hand held higher, perhaps indicating his atrophied lower legs. A dense crowd watches on the r., some of them painted in the ugly livid manner that T°oros Taronec°i [the artist] reserves for the adversaries of Christ.  At far r. the paralytic, now cured, walks off with his bed over his back. Adjacent text: Gospels in Armenian, commisioned by abbot Esayi Ncé°ec°i.
Description.note: Glajor, Armenia, first quarter of the fourteenth century (ca. 1300-1307).|~|Attributed to: T°oros Taronec°i.
Source: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Manuscript. Arm. Ms.1 [Glajor Gospel]  p. 336
Relation.isPartOf: Bible. N.T. Gospels. Armenian. Gladzori Avetaran.|~|Mathews & Sanjian.  Armenian gospel iconography, repr. pl. 65 disc., p. 140.

Subject: Hepaticae|~|Liverworts|~|Plants, Medicinal|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Roots (Botany)|~|Herbs|~|Polypodiaceae|~|Ferns
Title: Erba segarella. Three types of lingua cervina.
Description.abstract: Four plants, one individual plant and one group of three plants: Plant, top, "Segarella vel epaticha" (class Hepaticae, order Marchantiales, family Monocleaceae) Marchantia polymorpha, Common Liverwort, includes many convoluted and radiating leaflike structures  without a stem, green with some brown on edges. Three plants called "lingua cervina Scolopendria," names usually indicating (family Polypodiaceae) Phyllitis scolopendrium (formerly Asplenium scolopendrium or Scolopendrium vulgare), Hart's-tongue fern, Deer's-tongue fern, the first, center of page, a fairly realistic depiction of the latter, a central vertical stem with three tiers of long leaves, green with white roots, the second, middle r., sprouts or leaf-bearing stems arising from a rhizome or stout runner in a vertical row, green with brown and white shading on the roots, the third, bottom r., bears radiating leaves without a stem, green with white roots. Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.|~|Text beginning to l. of fourth plant: Lingua cervina alio modo in alio libro.|~|Text above fifth plant: [same as above].
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 10

Subject: Liliaceae|~|Verbenaceae|~|Plants, Medicinal|~|Bulbs (Botany)|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Iridaceae|~|Roots (Botany)|~|Herbs|~|Cyperaceae|~|Flowers
Title: Ciporo vel gioncho. Lilio. Berbena. Ermodattolo.
Description.abstract: Four plants: Plant, top l., "Ciporo vel gioncho" (family Cyperaceae) Cyperus sp. perhaps C. esculentus or C. longus, Chufa, Galingale, Earth Nut, three fanlike clusters of linear leaves growing from a rhizome or stout runner in a vertical row, green with brown root. Plant, top r., "Lilio" (family Liliaceae) probably Lilium candidum, Madonna Lily, an unbranched vertical stem with pointed clasping  large leaves, protruding from a bulbous, scaly base and bearing funnel-shaped flowers and elliptical buds at top, green with white flowers and light brown bulb. Plant, bottom l., "Berbena" (family Verbenaceae) probably Verbena officinalis, Ashthroat, Columbine, Vervain, a central vertical stem with tiers of long elliptical dentate leaves, larger leaves at the base, and terminating in flowers emerging from urceolate calyxes, green with blue flowers. Plant, bottom r., "Ermodattolo," perhaps (family Iridaceae) Hermodactylus tuberosus, Finger of Hermes, growing from a large tuberous root, an unbranched vertical stem bearing pointed clasping leaves and terminating in a large inflorescence, green with red and white flowers, and light brown root.  Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 100

Subject: Plants, Medicinal|~|Bulbs (Botany)|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Herbs
Title: Laticha. Ariella. Arteticha montana.
Description.abstract: Three plants: Plant, top, "Laticha," perhaps (family Compositae, Cichorium Tribe) Lactuca serriola, Prickly Lettuce, or L. sativa, Common Lettuce, bears radiating leaves each with a pronounced central spine and deeply dentate edges and two long unadorned peduncles bearing flowers, green with brown flowers and brown and red root, which is shaped like the head of a man. Plant, bottom l., "Ariella" an unbranched vertical stem with small, connate leaves and flowers at top, green with brown flowers and brownish red roots. Plant, bottom r., "Arteticha montana," perhaps a stylized representation of (family Leguminosae) Medicago marina, three branchings atop a vertical stem, with long opposite pointed elliptical leaves at the base, three-lobed structures at the top, and flowers protruding from the middle of the stem, green with white flowers and brownish red roots.  Figure associated with plant, "Laticha":  root in the form of the head of a man with long hair and beard.  Face is brown with red spots on checks and between eyes.  Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 101

Subject: Paeoniaceae|~|Plants, Medicinal|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Roots (Botany)|~|Herbs
Title: Erba lucqaede. Peonia. Erba musais flos album. Erba ruscharia.
Description.abstract: Four plants: Plant, top l., "Lucqaede" five straight, radiating stems, one bearing a flower, growing from a root shaped like a fish, green, the central stem with a light brown flower, light brown root, and half-white, half-green leaves. Plant, top r., "Peonia" (family Ranunculaceae, bout now often given its own family, Paeoniaceae) Paeonia officinalis, Garden Peony, an unbranched vertical stem with large leaves, green with brownish green roots. Plant, bottom l., "Musais flos album" bears long, thin, radiating odd-pinnate leaves and five rising stems each bearing a single flower, green with white flowers and brown roots. Plant, bottom r., "Ruscharia" three compound flowering branches with entire acuminate leaves terminating in a vertical stem, with large opposite dentate leaves near base, green with white flowers and brownish green roots.  Figure associated with plant, "Erba lucqaede":  root in the form of a brown fish with curved teeth, oval eyes, and dangling limb- or whisker-like fins.   Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 102

Subject: Plants, Medicinal|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Iridaceae|~|Roots (Botany)|~|Herbs
Title: Rapalis. Spatula ferida seu gladiolus alii sasiamon. Erba sancta maria piglar aut solivis. Gratiana.
Description.abstract: Four plants: Plant, top l., "Rapalis" bears radiating basal acuminate leaves with prominent central spines, and two rising stems carry flowers, green with white flowers, red and off-white roots, and leaves outlined in red. Plant, top r., "Spatula ferida" (family Iridaceae) Iris sp., Iris, Fleur-de-lys, Flag Gramen, bears radiating linear leaves and three rising stems each bearing flowers or pods green with white flowers and white rhizomes. The pod-like structures may indicate I. foetedissima, Gladwyn. Plant, bottom l., "Sancta maria piglar" five deeply dentate elliptical basal leaves on petioles, and three slender cylindrical stems apparently simple inflorescences, green with white roots. Plant, bottom r., "Gratiana" bears radiating deeply dentate leaves and three rising stems bearing funnel-shaped flowers, green with red flowers and white and green roots. Figure associated with plant, "Rapalis": on l. side of plant, a green and white snake coiled once, head facing plant with open mouth. Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 103

Subject: Plants, Medicinal|~|Compositae|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Roots (Botany)|~|Herbs|~|Plumbaginaceae|~|Flowers
Title: Two plants named Filopendula. Been rosso.
Description.abstract: Three plants, one group of two plants, "Filopendula," (family Compositae, Anthemis Tribe), probably Achillea millefolium, sp., Common Yarrow, Millefoil, upper l. bears long, thin pinnate leaves extending from central stem, green with white flowers at top portion of stem and brown roots.  Another of the same name, upper r., bears long, thin leaves extending from central stem, green with white flowers at top of stem and brown roots. One individual plant, "Been rosso" (family Plumbaginaceae) Limonium vulgare, formerly Statice limonium, Sea Lavender, Everlasting, lower center, bears long, thin, radiating stems with deeply undulate leaves, small flowers near ends of branches, green with white flowers and brown roots. Cf. Penzig, 2, p. 57 on Been rosso.  Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.|~|Text beginning to l. of second image: Been rosso non vidi ne fiore ne seme compiute fero lo disegno.
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 104

Subject: Plants, Medicinal|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Plantaginaceae|~|Herbs
Title: Sisamo. Sillium agreste.
Description.abstract: Two plants: Plant, top, "Sisamo" (family Pedaliaceae) Sesamum indicum, a central vertical stem with one tier of branches bearing seed pods, green with gray roots and black marked seed pods. Plant, bottom, "Sillium agreste," probably (family Plantaginaceae) Plantago sp. Plantain, but apparently not the species P. psyllium, an unbranched vertical stem with large leaves bearing a small cluster of flowers at top, green with gray roots and white flowers and black markings on leaves. Cf. Bedevian, pp. 469-470 on Plantago.  Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.|~|Text beginning to l. of second image: Sillium agreste sive aparienta questa erba vale asaldare le ferite et ulcere...
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 105

Subject: Plants, Medicinal|~|Compositae|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Iridaceae|~|Roots (Botany)|~|Rubiaceae|~|Herbs|~|Flowers
Title: Plion vel pilon. Pie leporino. Acorus. Gallitius sive Ghallitricus.
Description.abstract: Four plants: Plant, top l., "Plion vel pilon" five straight, radiating stems, each bearing pointed clasping leaves and terminating in a globular inflorescence, green with brown roots and brown flowers. Plant, top r., "Pie leporino" likely (family Compositae) Sonchus oleraceus, Sow Thistle, three tiers of alternating deeply cleft leaves on a vertical stem terminating in clusters of composite flowers, green with brown roots and brown flowers. Plant, bottom l., "Acorus" (family Iridaceae) Iris pseudacorus, Yellow Iris, Yellow Flag, Water Flag, bears linear, radiating leaves and two taller inflorescences, growing from extensive rhizomes, green with red roots and brown flowers. Plant, bottom r., "Gallitius sive Ghallitricus" (family Rubiaceae) Galium sp., probably Galium aparine, Goose-Grass, Aparine, Cleavers, a central vertical stem with two tiers of star-shaped leaf whorls, with small white flowers on slim peduncles rising from the center of each, green with brown roots and brown flowers.  Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 106

Subject: Plants, Medicinal|~|Compositae|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Herbs
Title: Herba Judaicha idest thetrait Alii pendalion. Two types of Concrealis. Giralia. Pes leporinus dynus Lagepos aut herba benedecta affrotia.
Description.abstract: Five plants, three individual plants, and one pair. Plant, upper l., "Herba Judaicha" three radiating stems bearing alternating three-lobed leaves, each stem ending in clusters of six-pointed flowers, green with red flowers and brown roots. Two plants, upper r., alternate forms of "Concrealis," the first, and larger, a vertical stem bearing three branches or compound leaves, with the pointed elliptical leaves or leaflets in an odd-pinnate arrangement, green with red roots, and the alternate form on a sketch upper center, above a cluster of thick roots, rudimentary basal leaves and peduncles bearing clusters of small flowers, green with white flowers and green roots. Plant, lower l., "Giralia" above a deep cluster of thick roots, radiating petioles bearing what appear to be small convex peltate leaves and longer peduncles bearing urceolate flowers, green with brown and red flowers and brown roots. Plant, lower r., "Pes leporinus" (family Compositae) genus uncertain, three radiating linear undulate leaves and two slightly taller peduncles bearing structures resembling composite disc-and-ray flowers, green with a brown flower on each stem and brown roots. Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 107

Subject: Plants, Medicinal|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Boraginaceae|~|Herbs|~|Flowers|~|Malvaceae
Title: Erba polmonella minore. Erba rufina. Altea id est malba vel malba vischio. Omalco velenosa.
Description.abstract: Four plants: Plant, top l., "Polmonella minore" (family Boraginaceae) Pulmonaria officinalis, Lung-wort, perhaps a smaller variant, stems arising from a rhizome or stout runner in a vertical row, each bearing pointed clasing leaves and many flowers, green with red flowers and dark green roots. Plant, top r., "Rufina" bears radiating leaves without a stem, green with brown root and white faces in the leaves. Plant, bottom l., "Altea id est malba vel malba vischio" (family Malvaceae) Althea officinalis, Marshmallow, five straight, radiating petioles bearing round leaves, and two straight, taller inflorescences bearing round and funnelform structures, green with blue flowers, brown and white inflorescent structures, white roots and large brown centers of green leaves. Plant, bottom r., "Omalco velenosa" an unbranched vertical stem with large clasping pointed leaves and terminating in two flowers with urceolate calyxes, green with reddish purple roots and blue and white flowers. Figures associated with plant, "Erba rufina":  a white human face on each of the three leaves of the plant.  Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 108

Subject: Plants, Medicinal|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Herbs
Title: Caro amalditignia regli. Leansihama.
Description.abstract: Two plants: Plant, top, "Caro amalditignia regli" three straight, radiating stems bearing pointed ovate leaves, with peduncle bearing a white circular structure emerging from the central stem, green with brown bulbous root and one white pod. Plant, bottom, "Leansihama" an unbranched vertical stem with large linear clasping leaves extending horizontally, green with brownish red roots.  Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 109

Subject: Liliaceae|~|Plants, Medicinal|~|Male nude|~|Bulbs (Botany)|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Snakes|~|Herbs|~|Angels|~|Antidotes|~|Flowers
Title: Erba villaries. Erba lilio montano.
Description.abstract: Two plants: Plant, top, "Villaries," bears radiating leaves and four rising stems, green with brown roots and flowers. Plant, bottom, "Lilio montano" ((family Liliaceae) probably Lilium candidum, Madonna Lily, a rosette of leaves, with central stem bearing funnelform flowers, green with brown flowers and bulblike roots. Figures associated with plant, "Villaries" apparently to indicate its effectiveness against snake bites,"contro amorsi di serpenti e vermini velenose": nude person, to r. of plant, is encircled and bitten by a green and brown snake on r. forearm.  Blood drips down.  Angel flying overhead touches him on head with l. hand, points to "Villaries" with r. hand.  Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.|~|Text beginning to l. of image: Erba villaries fa fiori citrini vale a caligine dochi sopra ogni altra herba ...
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 11

Subject: Plants, Medicinal|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Herbs
Title: Chapalanes laqua. Riacha.
Description.abstract: Two plants: Plant, top, "Chapalanes laqua" an unbranched vertical stem bearing small pointed elliptical leaves, curving 180 degrees at the top and terminating in a large funnel-shaped flower facing downward, growing from a bulb, brown with white flower. Plant, bottom, "Riacha" a central vertical stem with large pointed ovate leaves at base and on a central stem, smaller leaves or stipules and three tiers of infloresences terminating in a single flower, green with brown roots and white flowers.  Adjacent text: Italian herbal.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 110

Subject: Plants, Medicinal|~|Nymphaeaceae|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Herbs
Title: Erba angela. Ginoglios lingua canis. Two plants called Nenufarro vel piarano.
Description.abstract: Two plants, and a separate pair of plants: Plant,  upper l."Angela" arising from a rounded bulb, a single vertical stem bears pointed elliptical leaves extending at right angles, terminating in  three-branched inflorescence of five petaled flowers with pale margins and calyxes, and pale buds. Plant, upper r., "Ginoglios lingua canis" emerging from a carrot-like root, wide pointed acuminate basal leaves around a single vertical stem bearing buds and flowers. Two plants called "Nenufarro" (family Nymphaceae) perhaps Nuphar luteum, Yellow Water Lily, or Nymphaea alba, White Water Lily, the first, center, radiating petioles supporting large ovate leaves grow directly from a thick rhizome, and among them, five longer peduncles bear flowers at different stages of emergice from large calyxes, and the second, just below, a smaller version of "Nenufarro," similar except that the leaves are more circular and no rhizomes are shown.
Description.note: (Italy), ca. 1500.
Source: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]. [ca. 1500] MS 2 fol. 111

Subject: Plants, Medicinal|~|Herbal illustrations - Italy - 1500|~|Herbs|~|Flowers
Title: Two Stellaria. Two Antolla lupana. Antolla minor.
